factoid: The sounds had a more pleasurable and exhilarating effect on Rostóv than the previous sounds of firing.
Rostóv drew himself up.
Rostóv viewed the field of battle opening out before him from the hill.
Rostóv followed the movement of the Uhlans with his whole soul.
The Uhlans swooped down close to the French dragoons.
Something confused happened amid the smoke.
Five minutes later the Uhlans were galloping back.
The Uhlans were galloping back more to the left than to the place they had occupied.
Among the orange-colored Uhlans on chestnut horses and behind them, a large group of blue French dragoons on gray horses could be seen.
Rostóv, with his keen sportsman’s eye, was one of the first to catch sight of the blue French dragoons pursuing the Uhlans.
Nearer and nearer in disorderly crowds came the Uhlans and the French dragoons pursuing them.
Rostóv could already see how the men looked small at the foot of the hill.
The men jostled and overtook one another, waving their arms and sabers in the air.
Rostóv gazed at what was happening before him as at a hunt.
Rostóv felt instinctively that if the hussars struck at the French dragoons now, the French dragoons could not withstand them.
Rostóv felt that if a charge was to be made it must be done now or it would be too late.
A captain standing beside Rostóv was gazing like him with eyes fixed on the cavalry below them.
Rostóv said, "Andrew Sevastyánych! You know, we could crush them...."
The captain replied, "A fine thing too! and really..."
Rostóv touched his horse, galloped to the front of his squadron, and before he had time to finish giving the word of command the whole squadron was following him.
Rostóv did not know how or why he did it.
Rostóv acted as he did when hunting, without reflecting or considering.
Rostóv saw the dragoons near and that they were galloping in disorder.
Rostóv knew the dragoons could not withstand an attack.
Rostóv knew there was only that moment and that if he let it slip it would not return.
The bullets were whining and whistling so stimulatingly around Rostóv.
Rostóv’s horse was eager to go so Rostóv could not restrain himself.
Rostóv touched his horse, gave the word of command, and immediately the squadron rode at full trot downhill toward the dragoons.
Hardly had the squadron reached the bottom of the hill before their pace changed to a gallop.
The squadron’s pace grew faster and faster as they drew nearer to the Uhlans and the French dragoons who galloped after them.
The dragoons were now close at hand.
On seeing the hussars the foremost dragoons began to turn.
The dragoons behind began to halt.
Rostóv gave rein to his Donéts horse and galloped to intersect the path of the dragoons’ disordered lines.
One Uhlan stopped.
Another Uhlan on foot flung himself to the ground to avoid being knocked over.
A riderless horse fell in among the hussars.
Nearly all the French dragoons were galloping back.
Rostóv picked out one French dragoons on a gray horse and dashed after him.
On the way Rostóv came upon a bush and his horse cleared it.
Rostóv almost righted himself in his saddle.
Rostóv saw that he would immediately overtake the enemy he had selected.
The Frenchman was an officer by his uniform.
The French officer was going at a gallop, crouching on his gray horse, and urging it on with his saber.
Rostóv’s horse dashed its breast against the hindquarters of the officer’s horse, almost knocking it over.
Rostóv raised his saber and struck the French officer with it.
